key_points: Vice President Harris welcomes President Akufo-Addo of Ghana to the White House, highlighting the strong relationship between the United States and Ghana.
The bilateral relationship between the two nations began officially in 1957, though there are longer-standing ties.
Many Americans travel to Ghana to understand their ancestry and the history of slavery, signifying deep cultural connections.
Both nations share a commitment to democracy, as evidenced by Ghana's free and fair elections.
There's a mutual understanding that democracies are strengthened by full participation and weakened when individuals are excluded.
The two countries are also committed to global health, collaborating and sharing resources to tackle COVID-19 and prepare for future pandemics.
The United States, a member of COVAX and the African Union, has donated over 1.2 million doses of the Moderna vaccine to Ghana and plans to send more than 1.3 million Pfizer vaccine doses.
The countries are working to expand their economic relationship, with American companies ramping up their presence in Ghana.
Vice President Harris commends the Ghanaian government for creating a confidence-inspiring environment through respect for the rule of law and human rights.
The leaders look forward to continued collaboration, including in the context of the United Nations Security Council.
spokespersons: President Akufo-Addo (President of the Republic of Ghana)
